abstract: Many civilians in Rafah are sheltering in rickety tents made of plastic and wood and say there is nowhere left in Gaza to avoid Israeli shelling.

abstract: Hundreds gathered in a Greenwich Village church to pay their respects to the transgender activist Cecilia Gentili, who died this week at 52.

abstract: Zhouqin Burnikel returns to the Saturday puzzle page in style.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Although this is Zhouqin Burnikel’s 79th New York Times crossword, it has been more than six long years since we’ve solved a Saturday grid by her. She is a constructor with a devoted following; many solvers who started in the last decade grew to love her wit and subtle style in themed puzzles on Mondays and Tuesdays. She shines just as brightly in a challenging grid like this one, which is technically themeless, although it does feature a particular celebratory event that we discover as we solve.
headline: Rocked, So to Speak

abstract: For almost 20 years, Combatants For Peace has called for non-violence and an “end to Israel’s occupation of Palestine.” But after Oct. 7, some attendees are more hesitant to speak out about their activism. Times reporters attended one of their sessions.

abstract: In her new novel, “Leaving,” Roxana Robinson reunites a former couple. One of them is divorced; the other is still married. What now?
lead_paragraph: Every love story needs an obstacle, someone or something that threatens to keep the lovers apart. What obstacles are suitable for a contemporary American love story? The writer of such a story may wish to avoid the over-communication, the tolerance (real or performed) and the jadedness that dispel romantic tension. Can lovers still be “star-crossed,” doomed from the start to labor under a “malign star”?
headline: A Tale of Midlife Love With a Bombshell Ending
keywords: Books and Literature;Leaving: A Novel (Book);Robinson, Roxana

abstract: On the 25th anniversary of the director’s death, two film scholars have published “Kubrick: An Odyssey.”
lead_paragraph: The passions, obsessions, habits, talents and fears that shaped the extraordinary movies of Stanley Kubrick were well chewed over in his lifetime. Some of the reporting came from those who knew him; other impressions came from journalists who didn’t know him, but enjoyed the digging. It was easy quarrying, because there was so much rich topsoil. A son of the Bronx who became the self-styled squire of Childwickbury Manor in Hertfordshire, England, Kubrick was a visionary filmmaker whose greatest works — including “Paths of Glory” and “Dr. Strangelove,” “Lolita” and “2001: A Space Odyssey,” “The Shining” and “A Clockwork Orange” — are as vital and prescient about culture and society today as they were when they blazed through the second half of the 20th century.
headline: A New Biography Tackles the Remarkable Career of Stanley Kubrick
keywords: Kubrick, Stanley;Content Type: Personal Profile;Books and Literature;Kubrick: An Odyssey (Book);Kolker, Robert;Abrams, Nathan (Author);Movies;2001: A SPACE ODYSSEY (MOVIE);Dr Strangelove: Or How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Bomb (Movie);Lolita (Movie);Eyes Wide Shut (Movie);Paths of Glory (Movie);A Clockwork Orange (Movie);The Shining (Movie)

abstract: Thoughts on the coolest boy in Ontario.
lead_paragraph: Our elementary school was set deep in the rural Ontario countryside, nestled in the forest beside the local dump. In the late 1990s, when I was in sixth grade, the school had a drug bust in which more than 20 kids were suspended and charged with possession of marijuana, magic mushrooms and ecstasy. I was not one of those kids.
headline: My First Cigarette Was My Last

abstract: It’s possible that the listed limits in a building’s offering plans are lower than what city code allows. Here’s how to find out.
lead_paragraph: Q: We have two rooftop lounges on top of our Hell’s Kitchen condominium building, where I serve on the board. Residents use them and sometimes rent them for private events. There are maximum capacities for the lounges listed in the building’s offering plans, but they seem too low — the spaces have double doors and double exits for easy evacuation in case of emergency. We were never told to post capacity limits for the residents, as public places are. How do we find out how many people can legally be in these lounges at the same time?
headline: Our Condo Building Has a Huge Roof. Why Aren’t More People Allowed on It?
keywords: Real Estate and Housing (Residential);Roofs;Condominiums;Accidents and Safety

abstract: Positions have hardened on both sides in the face of the Gaza war, but some activists refuse to give up hope. They let us sit in on one of their meetings.

headline: These Israelis and Palestinians Are Still Working for Peace. Just Quietly.

abstract: Alexei Ratmansky, arguably the most important ballet choreographer today, has made a deeply personal first work as artist in residence that reflects his Ukrainian roots.
lead_paragraph: For the choreographer Alexei Ratmansky, the last two years have brought an uncomfortable intermingling of life and art. Known for ballets that combine wit with an almost surrealistic imagination, he has found his thoughts drawn insistently toward the war in Ukraine, the country where he spent his early years and began his dancing career, where he met his wife and where their families still live.

abstract: Astronomers tracked the entry of a small space rock into Earth’s atmosphere, and then meteorite hunters made an unexpected discovery.
lead_paragraph: Scientists have found pieces of a meteorite that fell near Berlin just after midnight on Jan. 21. It is a rare find, from an asteroid that was identified just before it entered Earth’s atmosphere. Only a handful of such events in the recent past have allowed astronomers to trace an incoming rock’s origin in the solar system.
headline: Fragments of Asteroid With Mystery Origin Are Found Outside Berlin
keywords: Meteors and Meteorites;Asteroids;Solar System;Mercury (Planet);Research;Berlin (Germany)

abstract: The White House’s cloistered nature reflects the concern of aides who worry that even small mistakes will be amplified. Lately, the president has burst through that bubble, with mixed results.
lead_paragraph: Aides have President Biden take the shorter stairs to board Air Force One. When it comes to news conferences, they yell loudly — and quickly — to end the questions, sometimes stealing a classic awards show tactic and playing loud music to signal the conclusion of the event. And forget about regular interviews with major news publications, including a traditional presidential sit-down on Super Bowl Sunday.
headline: Inside Biden’s Protective White House

abstract: Poland voted out authoritarianism. Reproductive rights tipped the scales.
lead_paragraph: Poland recently ousted its right-wing, nationalist Law and Justice Party. In 2020, a party-appointed tribunal severely restricted the country’s abortion rights, sparking nationwide protests and an opposition movement. After a trip to Poland, the Times Opinion columnist Michelle Goldberg came to recognize that similar dynamics could prevail in the United States in 2024. In this audio essay, she argues that Joe Biden’s campaign should take note of what a “powerful mobilizing force the backlash to abortion bans can be.”
headline: Don’t Underestimate the Mobilizing Force of Abortion
keywords: audio-neutral-informative;Poland;Politics and Government;Democracy (Theory and Philosophy);Polls and Public Opinion;Tusk, Donald;Law and Legislation;Abortion;Law and Justice (Poland);Women and Girls;Presidential Election of 2024;Trump, Donald J;Biden, Joseph R Jr;United States Politics and Government;Europe

abstract: The Supreme Court can put a stop to the former president’s attempts to delay his criminal trial.

abstract: Though we’d welcome baked Buffalo wings, bacon-Cheddar dip and Frito pie on any given Sunday.
lead_paragraph: New York Times Cooking isn’t known for its sports coverage — you’ll want to head over to The Athletic for that — but one thing we do know is snacks. We know crunchy snacks. We know melty snacks. We know savory snacks and sweet snacks and salty snacks and sour snacks and spicy snacks. So while we may struggle to explain the particulars of the Big Sports Game tomorrow, we certainly have the snacks quotient covered, and you should make Ali Slagle’s baked Buffalo wings. They’re easy, fast and a fan favorite: That classic mix of garlicky hot sauce and funky blue cheese is always a winner. We’d say to set out plenty of napkins, but let’s be real, everyone will be licking their fingers clean.
headline: Super Snacks for the Super Bowl

abstract: Cupid is no lexicographer. So, before Valentine’s Day, we looked into the evolution of the word “crush.”
